lesson: Keep controls minimal and responsive: Arrow/WASD + one action is enough for Atari-scale fun.
Add tiny juice (screen shake, bleep) but keep the loop readable—clarity > effects.
Ship a playable loop first; add polish only after the loop feels good.
Retro readability matters: high contrast, chunky pixels, and clear feedback.
Rotation-based movement needs different mobile UX than paddle games — joystick axis mapping (X=rotate, Y=thrust) is workable but not as tight as keyboard.
Screen-wrap physics needs safe-zone spawning logic to avoid unfair deaths on wave transitions.
For discrete-direction games, swipe detection beats virtual buttons or joysticks — match the input method to the game's movement model.
Puzzle games need animation bookkeeping (slide sources, merge targets, new spawns) even though the logic is simple — the feel lives in the transitions.
Rendering HUD info on canvas instead of DOM keeps embed mode clean and avoids duplicate UI state management.
When representing 3D grids in 2D, showing all layers simultaneously beats layer-switching UX — players need full board visibility for strategic games.
For board game AI, check immediate wins/blocks before running minimax — it's both faster and ensures the AI never misses an obvious move at any search depth.
64 tap targets on mobile is viable if cells fill available space and ghost previews confirm selection — don't hide information behind navigation when spatial awareness matters.
Multi-level games benefit from distinct control schemes per level — jump/duck for side-scrolling vs lane-switching for vertical climbing keeps the same inputs feeling fresh.
Progress bars in endless-feeling runner levels transform anxiety into motivation — players push harder when they can see the finish line approaching.
Grid-based movement with player-driven terrain modification (digging) adds emergent strategy to simple games — players create their own level layout through play.
Auto-attacking tongue that extends through tunnel cells creates a natural risk/reward loop — longer reach means catching more ants but also more exposure to fire ants.
Horizontal-only movement games map perfectly to two-button mobile controls — when the game fits, simpler inputs beat joysticks every time.
Visual fill-level feedback (beaker filling up) turns abstract progress into satisfying physical metaphor — players intuitively understand how close they are to level completion.
